thread.title: Former Detroit high school principal agrees to plead guilty amid EAA probe
thread.title_full: Former Detroit high school principal agrees to plead guilty amid EAA probe

author: Khalil AlHajal | kalhajal@mlive.com
title: Former Detroit high school principal agrees to plead guilty amid EAA probe
text:
Comments 
DETROIT, MI -- A former high school principal targeted in an FBI investigation of contracts and a possible kickback scheme at the state-run Education Achievement Authority revealed Thursday afternoon that she plans to plead guilty. 
Kenyetta Wilboure-Snapp has yet to be charged with a crime, but she's already agreed to a plea deal that would have her admitting to tax evasion and bribes worth $58,000, according to a report co-written by Rochelle Riley , a Detroit Free Press columnist who featured the former educator in 2010. 
She told the newspaper federal agents raided her home, "looking for a bomb and they got a cap gun." 
The governor's office earlier Thursday confirmed that the FBI is investigating the 15-school, state-run education reform district in Detroit after an internal review raised suspicions of questionable activity. 
"We always work to make sure resources intended to help children are used to help children with their education," said David Murray, a spokesperson for Gov. Rick Snyder's office. "... The governor's office has been in full coordination in reporting and bringing to light concerns with appropriate state and federal law enforcement agencies." 
EAA officials couldn't be reached for comment. 
The FBI investigation was first reported by the Detroit News , citing unnamed sources, who said the probe involved contracts that may have been awarded to vendors who paid kickbacks. 
Wilbourn-Snapp resigned as principal of Mumford High School last year. 
She was known as a former Army reservist who wore a military uniform while walking the halls of Mumford, where she was placed after making improvements at Denby High School and developing a reputation as a "turnaround specialist." 
The state created the EAA in 2011 by taking over 15 low-performing Detroit schools, including Mumford, and implementing alternative education strategies. 
Proposals to expand the district to other parts of the state were stalled by dismal test scores and other complaints. 
Veronica Conforme, who was named new chancellor of the EAA in June 2014, announced a restructuring earlier this year that would have all 15 schools run autonomously, would be run autonomously with decisions on programs, personnel and professional development directly on school leaders.
